prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Structure and kinematics of the star-forming regions and galaxy quenching - 1st target
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: We will use ALMA band-7 continuum+line observations to determine the IR-based SFRs and to map the location and kinematics of the star-forming regions on 4 "dusty nuggets" (compact, massive, dusty star-forming galaxies) at z=2-3, and thereby confirm their evolutionary link to the "red nugget" (massive, compact, quiescent galaxies) at z~2. a) The location and structure of the star-forming regions would verify whether dusty nuggets are as remarkably compact (sub-kpc sizes) as the red nuggets. b) By combining the ALMA fluxes with mid-to-far data from Spitzer/Herschel we will model the IR SED of dusty nuggets to determine accurate SFRs, M_dust and also M_gas, obtaining a direct estimate of their quenching timescales. c) The CO velocity map will reveal the intrinsic kinematics of the gas (rotation vs. dispersion) with unprecedented spatial resolution.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We use three channels for continuum detection and one centered in the CO line. For all 4 channels we chose the lowest-resolution spectral mode with a total band width of 7.5GHz. As described above, the broadest bandwidth provides high spectral resolution for the redshifted line. We will bin the spectral data to 150km/s to increase the S/N per resolution element.
Data rate and time constraints are no issues for this proposal.

A key goal of this proposal is to determine whether dusty nuggets are compact below their optical sizes, or they are significantly more extended (Fig. 3). Thus we require an extended, high-resolution configuration.
In cycle 2 we resquested C34-7. The closest configuration in cycle 3 is C36-6, for a resolution of 0.08''.

*** This is a resubmission of an accepted high priority (top 10%-20%) proposal from cycle 2 2013.1.00205.S. We submit this proposal to Cycle 3 with minor corrections in the observing mode to address the comments of the TAC (see below). If the observations are finished in Cycle 2 we will only require the additional observing time on the 4 galaxies included in this proposal. ***
- Frequency
Using Band-7 offers a perfect balance between the field of view, resolution and sensitivity required to address our science goals. At the redshifts of the sample, z=2.1-2.4, Band-7 is redshifted to 300 microns (redward of the IR peak), which is an excellent tracer of the SFR, and combined with other mid-to-far IR data, will allow us to estimate very robust dust and gas properties from IR SED modeling.
Following the comments of the TAC, we modified the spectral setup to detect the CO lines. At the reshift of our galaxies, the CO(8-7) and CO(9-8) lines can be observed in Band-7 allowing us to measure both the dust continuum emission and the emission lines.
- Sensitivity
Our cycle 2 proposal focused on detecting the dust continuum emission at 0.9mm with high spatial resolution. The addition of CO spectroscopy creates a much richer dataset enabling, for the first time, to spatially-resolve the velocity field of the most compact SFGs at z~2.
- CO line sensitivity : Based on the SFR~300 M_sun/yr and total IR luminosities, L_TIR~10^12.6 L_sun, of these galaxies we estimate a CO(3-2) flux of ~2mJy (e.g. Tacconi et al. 2013; Daddi et al. 2010,2015). Higher order transitions have lower luminosity. We estimate L_co(8-7) = 0.3 L_co(3-2)(Carilli et al 2010). However, the flux increases as the frecuency squared: S(8-7) = 0.3 * (921/345) = 2.1 S(3-2). The total flux divided in 5 resolution elements (probing the galaxy core) and detected with high significance (5sigma) requires sigma(8-7) = 2/(5*5) * 2.1 = 170uJy/beam. Dusty nuggets are extremely dense and have high velociy dispersions (FWHM~600 km/s; Barro et al. 2014b; Nelson et al. 2014). Therefore, using a spectral binning of 150 km/s we can resolve the line in velocity space and reach the required sensitivity with 52 min on-target. The program requires a total of 3.5h to observe all 4 dusty nuggets.
- Continuum sensitivity : Based on the best-fit IR templates to Spitzer/Herschel data, we estimate a Band-7 flux for the dusty nuggets of S_0.9mm = 2mJy. The stellar profiles of dusty nuggets are almost x2 smaller than those of other SFGs at the same redshift (Fig. 1). The 52 min integrations would determine if the IR flux is distributed in a compact or extended star-forming component (Fig. 3), reaching a sensitivity of 20 uJy/beam (5sigma) in the case of a extended (10 resolution elements) star-forming profile.
Note that the high SNR per resolution element is a critical element of our proposal which aims at probing the extent and location of the dust (mm) emission relative to the rest-frame optical stellar emission probed by HST/WFC3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The discovery of the "red nugget" population (massive, compact, quiescent galaxies) at z=2 indicates that early passive galaxies were remarkably compact compared to their present-day elliptical counterparts. Recent observations have identified a population of compact, star forming galaxies (so-called "dusty nuggets") that appear to be the direct progenitors of the red nugget galaxies. While several pieces of indirect evidence link these two populations, ALMA observations will provide the smoking gun confirmation that dusty nugget galaxies are the star forming progenitors of the first generation of red sequence galaxies. Therefore, we request 3.5 hours to obtain Band-7 luminosities, continuum and CO maps on 4 dusty nuggets to: (a) determine if their star-forming components are as compact as the stellar components of red nuggets, (b) verify a short quenching (gas depletion) timescales consistent with the rapid build up the red nugget population and (c) resolve their gas kinematics.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: This proposal is a resubmission of an accepted high priority (top 10%-20%) proposal fro cycle 2 2013.1.00205.S. We submit this proposal to Cycle 3 with some improvements to the observing strategy following the indications of the TAC.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
